content.body: Since we don't specify `console`, dunno if it qualifies as a "namespace", but it's certainly like one and it's expose to JavaScript so...

content.body:
> <@usharma:igalia.com> Since we don't specify `console`, dunno if it qualifies as a "namespace", but it's certainly like one and it's expose to JavaScript so...

Personally I’ve thought of globalThis.console as a singleton instance with methods of the Console class

https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_class_console

content.body:
> <@aclaymore:matrix.org> Personally I’ve thought of globalThis.console as a singleton instance with methods of the Console class
> https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_class_console

Interesting, I'd been referring to the whatwg console spec, didn't think about this class. Is this class also implemented in browsers or is it just a Node thing?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @aclaymore:matrix.org

Personally I’ve thought of globalThis.console as a singleton instance with methods of the Console class

https://nodejs.org/api/console.html#console_class_console

Interesting, I'd been referring to the whatwg console spec, didn't think about this class. Is this class also implemented in browsers or is it just a Node thing?

content.body:
```
❯ node -e "console.log(console.Console)"
[Function: Console]
```
yep you can do console.constructor in browsers. But can't actually call it

```
❯ eshost -e "console.Console"
#### JavaScriptCore

TypeError: undefined is not an object (evaluating 'console.Console')

#### SpiderMonkey
undefined

#### V8
undefined
```
content.formatted_body:
❯ eshost -e "console.Console"
#### JavaScriptCore

TypeError: undefined is not an object (evaluating 'console.Console')

#### SpiderMonkey
undefined

#### V8
undefined

content.body: * yep you can do console.constructor in browsers. But can't actually use it

m.new_content.body: yep you can do console.constructor in browsers. But can't actually use it

content.body: `console.Console` is node. in browser's it's `console.constructor`
ah, gotcha
The constructor doesn't work, but is a hit that console is an instance
you're right. The existence of `console.constructor` means it's an instance and not a namespace
content.formatted_body: you're right. The existence of console.constructor means it's an instance and not a namespace

content.body: * The constructor doesn't work, but is a hint that console is an instance

m.new_content.body: The constructor doesn't work, but is a hint that console is an instance

content.body: yeah
it’s conceptually a namespace tho - “a singleton instance of a class whose constructor you can’t use” is just a misuse of a class :-p
historically the receiver mattered, and you had to console.log.bind(console), but i don’t think you have to do that anywhere anymore
Another instance like thing is that (in some hosts) it has state. With methods like groupStart and groupEnd
I will admit that it is namespace like in a lot of ways
* I will admit that it is 'namespace-like' in a lot of ways

m.new_content.body: I will admit that it is 'namespace-like' in a lot of ways

content.body:
> <@ljharb:matrix.org> it’s conceptually a namespace tho - “a singleton instance of a class whose constructor you can’t use” is just a misuse of a class :-p

Node allows more to be constructed, so more like a class there
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @ljharb:matrix.org
it’s conceptually a namespace tho - “a singleton instance of a class whose constructor you can’t use” is just a misuse of a class :-p
Node allows more to be constructed, so more like a class there

content.body: True enough
it’s a weird one tho. the point about state in group and performance is a good one
and the whatwg spec does say it's a namespace. So I could be convinced either way depending on the weighting of the different bits of 'evidence' 🙂
I'd call it a historical oddity due to ad-hoc decision making, myself
see #whatwg: https://matrixlogs.bakkot.com/WHATWG/2021-07-14#L13
